nodes.text: The Almost Ideal Demand System (AIDS) provides a practical, flexible demand system that satisfies choice axioms, aggregates exactly over consumers, is consistent with household budget data, is simple to estimate, and is recommended as a vehicle for testing and improving conventional demand analysis
Specification: AIDS is derived from a PIGLOG class cost function log c(u,p) = (1-u) log a(p) + u log b(p) with log a(p) and log b(p) chosen as flexible log-linear forms leading to cost function (4)

Claim: The AIDS budget-share demand functions are wi = ai + sum_j yij log pj + beta_i log(x/P) with price index log P defined in (9), and follow from Shephard duality (price derivatives of cost give quantities)

Claim: AIDS is a flexible functional form giving an arbitrary first-order approximation to any demand system (derived or not from utility maximization) because parameters can match local derivatives of true demand functions

Claim: AIDS satisfies key theoretical restrictions by linear parameter constraints: adding-up (sum ai =1, sum beta_i =0, sum_j yij =0), homogeneity (sum_j yij =0 across j), and Slutsky symmetry (yij = yji)

Method: Estimation strategy includes (a) approximating P by Stone price index P* to linearize and estimate equation-by-equation by OLS, (b) concentrated nonlinear maximum likelihood or iteration to estimate full system, and (c) testing restrictions by likelihood-ratio or F tests

Application method: Aggregation over households achieved via PIGLOG/PIGL structure with household equivalence scale kh and representative budget x/k, allowing exact aggregation under stated assumptions and limited taste variation

Empirical method: Authors estimate AIDS on annual UK 1954-1974 data for eight nondurables using P* first, test homogeneity equation-by-equation, then impose symmetry and reestimate using full price index P with a parsimonious variance structure for residuals

Result: Unconstrained OLS estimates using P* show many significant yij price effects, classification of food and housing as necessities (beta positive/low), general price inelasticity except transport, and notable row-sum deviations indicating rejection of homogeneity in some equations

Result: System tests show homogeneity is decisively rejected in several equations and full symmetry restriction is rejected by likelihood-ratio tests; imposing homogeneity often introduces positive serial correlation in residuals

Claim: Imposing homogeneity can induce serial correlation because omitted dynamic or distributional variables (stocks, time trends, price expectations, or a nonconstant k index) may be correlated with expenditure and prices, so rejection of homogeneity may reflect omitted dynamics

Result: Symmetric parameter estimates violate concavity (Slutsky negativity) for parts of the sample (positive eigenvalues), producing implausible compensated own-price elasticities (e.g., fuel), indicating the need for further parameter restrictions to ensure concave homogeneous cost functions for welfare applications

Result: First-difference (time-differenced) estimation reduces some homogeneity rejections (only a few goods reject) and yields expenditure elasticities and parameter values similar to levels estimates for many goods; allowing intercept trends can alleviate some conflicts with representative consumer hypothesis

Conclusion: AIDS fits budget-share data well and offers desirable theoretical properties and practical estimability, and thus provides a useful platform for extending demand analysis to include dynamics, household distribution effects, price expectations, or intertemporal structure

Limitation: The simple static AIDS should not be regarded as a fully satisfactory explanation of consumer behavior because it omits dynamics, possible nonseparabilities, household distribution variation (k), and may require additional restrictions to ensure negativity and identification of some parameters (a0)
